Mark shares his feedback on his Class A CDL Cheat Sheet

questions.question: Be sure that your wheel bearing/seals are:
questions.answerB: Shiny.
questions.answerC: Rusted.
questions.explanation: During an inspection, ensure that the wheel bearing/seals are not leaking.

questions.question: What kind of brakes do most newer heavy-duty trucks use?
questions.answerB: Dual air brakes
questions.answerC: Triple air brakes
questions.explanation: Most newer heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems. A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems which use a single set of brake controls.

questions.question: When entering a curve, you should:
questions.answerB: Use the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Downshift.
questions.explanation: You should always slow down to a safe speed and shift into a lower gear before entering a curve.

questions.question: When starting an engine:
questions.answerB: Warning lights should turn on, then quickly turn off.
questions.answerC: Coolant temperatures should decrease.
questions.explanation: After a vehicle is started, the warning lights and buzzers should go out after a few seconds. If the warning signals do not turn off, there may be something wrong with the vehicle.

questions.question: If the brakes pull to one side or the other when used:
questions.answerB: They need to be checked.
questions.answerC: They will be the most effective.
questions.explanation: If the brakes pull to one side or the other when used, it is an indication of brake trouble.

questions.question: When driving, knowing what is happening behind you is:
questions.answerB: Important.
questions.answerC: Distracting.
questions.explanation: To travel safely, it is essential that you know what is happening on all sides of your vehicle at all times. Use your mirrors frequently to help you remain aware of your surroundings.

questions.question: Some water and compressor oil is usually found in the compressed air within an air brake system. The water and compressor oil:
questions.answerA: Are necessary for the proper function of the system.
questions.answerB: Should take up about 10 percent of the tank.
questions.answerC: Should be removed regularly.
questions.explanation: If water and compressor oil are left to build up in an air brake system, the system can be damaged. Air storage tanks are equipped with drains to allow this accumulation to be removed. Manually controlled drains should be operated at the end of each day of driving.

questions.question: When making a left turn where there are two available turn lanes, a driver should begin the turn in the rightmost lane because:
questions.answerA: It will be easier for the driver to keep track of turning vehicles on their left than on their right.
questions.answerB: The vehicle will be able to turn more quickly.
questions.answerC: Other vehicles will get out of the turning vehicle's way.
questions.explanation: If making a left turn where there is more than one available turn lane, you should always choose to begin your turn in the rightmost lane. Large vehicles often have to swing right to make left turns. Because of this, it is safer for you to have other left-turning traffic to your left instead of to your right. This will allow you to have the best possible view of other turning vehicles and will lower the risk of your vehicle colliding with them.

questions.question: When doing a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Always go through the steps in the same order.
questions.answerB: Be as quick as possible.
questions.answerC: Not worry about small mechanical issues.
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.

questions.question: When traveling in heavy traffic, the safest driving speed is:
questions.answerB: The speed of surrounding traffic.
questions.answerC: A speed much slower than the flow of surrounding traffic.
questions.explanation: In heavy traffic, it is safest to match the speed of surrounding vehicles. Vehicles traveling in the same direction at the same speed are unlikely to collide. However, you should not exceed legal speed limits.

questions.question: One way to avoid becoming an aggressive driver is to:
questions.answerA: Talk on your cell phone while driving.
questions.answerB: Question others' driving abilities.
questions.answerC: Set realistic expectations regarding travel time.
questions.explanation: To help avoid frustration, which can lead to aggressive driving behavior, you should begin a trip with realistic expectations about your travel time. Plan ahead to allow time for potential traffic delays. Other strategies to help prevent aggressive driving behavior include driving an appropriate speed and keeping a reasonable following distance; avoiding making gestures at other drivers; and keeping your hands on the steering wheel.

questions.question: When pulled off on the side of the road:
questions.answerA: A driver should keep the driver’s side door open.
questions.answerB: A driver should turn on the emergency flashers.
questions.answerC: The driver should wave their arms.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, make sure to use your four-way emergency flashers. This is particularly important at night.

questions.question: Hydroplaning:
questions.answerB: Usually happens when vehicles are traveling faster than 65 mph.
questions.answerC: Can occur with a minimal amount of water on the roadway.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning is an effect in which a vehicle's tires lose traction with the surface of the road and instead glide along a layer of water. There does not have to be a large amount of water on the road for this to occur.

questions.question: When completing an offset back/left parking maneuver, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then back to the left.
questions.answerB: Drive straight back, then pull forward to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull straight forward, then drive straight back.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/left parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the left. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: You should not use your mirrors.
questions.answerB: You should use your mirrors.
questions.answerC: You should not use your turn signals.
questions.explanation: Always use your turn signals and check your mirrors when changing lanes.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerB: Are acceptable to be used on tires in the rear of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable to be used if carrying a light load.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims with welding repairs are never safe to use.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection and looking into the fifth wheel gap, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure there is a gap between the kingpin and the locking jaws.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.
questions.answerC: Make sure the locking jaws are loose.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a tractor/trailer coupling, look into the fifth wheel gap and make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.

questions.question: If you are turning left at an intersection where there are two available turn lanes:
questions.answerA: It is best to use the right lane.
questions.answerB: It doesn’t matter which lane you use.
questions.answerC: It is best to use the left lane.
questions.explanation: You may have to swing right to safely make a left turn. If there are two left turn lanes available at an intersection, you should always begin your turn in the rightmost lane.

questions.question: If you are convicted of a traffic violation:
questions.answerA: The State will inform your employer.
questions.answerB: You must tell your employer.
questions.answerC: You must tell the shipper.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any kind of traffic violation, in any type of vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days. You must also inform your motor vehicle licensing agency of the violation within 30 days if the conviction happened in another jurisdiction. This rule does not apply to parking infractions.

questions.question: Cargo being transported should be checked:
questions.answerB: Before the trip and again within the first 50 miles of the trip.
questions.answerC: Only by the loading personnel.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be inspected before beginning a trip, within the first 50 miles of the trip, and every three hours or 150 miles traveled thereafter. Cargo should be inspected every time the driver stops to take a break. The driver of a truck transporting cargo is responsible for the cargo being safely secured throughout the trip.

questions.question: An applicant for a CDL must be a minimum of:
questions.answerB: 21 years old.
questions.answerC: 25 years old.
questions.explanation: In Vermont, you must be at least 18 years old to obtain a CDL. To be licensed to operate in interstate commerce, you must be at least 21 years old.

questions.question: Steering wheel play should be no more than:
questions.answerB: 50 degrees.
questions.answerC: 75 degrees.
questions.explanation: A steering wheel should have no more than 10 degrees of play. This is equal to about two inches of movement at the rim of a 20-inch wheel. If there is more play than this, it may be difficult to steer.

questions.question: Some air brake systems introduce alcohol into the system to:
questions.answerA: Make the brakes work without squeaking.
questions.answerB: Prevent ice from forming in the brake system.
questions.answerC: Prevent people from breathing the air from the system.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems contain an alcohol evaporator. An evaporator introduces alcohol into the system to help inhibit the formation of ice in cold weather.

questions.question: If driving through flowing water or a large puddle, you should:
questions.answerB: Gently apply the brakes.
questions.answerC: Try to stop in the water.
questions.explanation: It is best to avoid driving through large puddles or moving water. If there is no way to avoid driving through water, you should slow down, shift into a low gear, and gently apply the brakes. Pressing linings against the brake drums or discs will keep water, mud, silt, and sand from getting inside the brake mechanisms.

questions.question: The ____ are activated by an electric switch that is triggered by the brake pedal.
questions.answerB: Turn signals
questions.answerC: Brake lights
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with air brakes, the brake lights are activated when the brake pedal is pushed and air pressure moves an electric switch. With the application of air pressure, the switch will then turn on the brake lights.

questions.question: Alcohol evaporators are:
questions.answerB: Used to introduce alcohol into air brake systems.
questions.answerC: Only allowed in the northern parts of the state.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems have alcohol evaporators, which introduce alcohol into the braking system to help prevent the formation of ice.

questions.question: If you are driving in fog, you should not:
questions.answerB: Slow down.
questions.answerC: Use your high beam lights.
questions.explanation: If you must drive in fog, be sure to slow down. Turn on your flashers and low beam headlights.

questions.question: You should not use your mirrors:
questions.answerB: When making a turn.
questions.answerC: To determine how fast you are traveling.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should be a part of your driving routine, it is particularly important to check your mirrors when changing lanes, turning, merging, and making tight maneuvers.

questions.question: If you are disqualified from driving:
questions.answerA: Your employer will be notified by the state.
questions.answerB: You must notify your employer within two business days.
questions.answerC: You must notify your employer within a month.
questions.explanation: You must notify your employer within two business days if your license is suspended, revoked, or canceled, or if you are otherwise disqualified from driving.

questions.question: If asked by a law enforcement officer to take a test to determine your blood alcohol concentration (BAC):
questions.answerA: You can refuse to take the test without a penalty.
questions.answerB: You can refuse taking the test but will be required to pay a $50 fine.
questions.answerC: You will lose your CDL if you refuse to take the test.
questions.explanation: Most states have an Implied Consent Law, which means that by driving a vehicle on the state's roads, you have agreed to undergo a drug or alcohol test if a police officer asks you to do so. If you refuse to submit to a test, you will lose your operating privileges. Make sure you are aware of the laws for every state in which you drive.

questions.question: What is a retarder?
questions.answerA: A device that prevents a vehicle from going too fast
questions.answerB: A device that prevents a vehicle from being too loud
questions.answerC: A device that improves a vehicle's gas mileage
questions.explanation: Retarders help to slow vehicles, reducing drivers' need to use brakes.

questions.question: Cargo with a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Can make a vehicle likely to tip over.
questions.answerB: Is encouraged in inclement weather.
questions.answerC: Is required on some roads.
questions.explanation: Cargo with a high center of gravity makes a vehicle more likely to tip over than cargo with a low center of gravity. For this reason, it is important that the weight of cargo be distributed as low as possible.

questions.question: Cargo should be covered:
questions.answerB: To hide the materials.
questions.answerC: To make it more difficult to steal.
questions.explanation: You should cover your cargo to protect people from the cargo if it spills, as well as to protect the cargo from the weather.

questions.question: When stopping, you should:
questions.answerA: Press down the brake pedal quickly.
questions.answerB: Press down the brake pedal gradually.
questions.answerC: Lift up the brake pedal quickly.
questions.explanation: When stopping, press down the brake pedal smoothly and gradually.

questions.question: Once the air tanks are at an air pressure level of 125 psi, the air compressor governor will:
questions.answerA: Stop the compressor from pumping air.
questions.answerB: Release air from the tanks.
questions.answerC: Begin pumping air into the tanks.
questions.explanation: An air compressor governor will stop the compressor from pumping air once the air tanks are at an air pressure level around 125 psi. This air pressure level is referred to as the "cut-out" level.

questions.question: When you must travel down a hill, when should you switch into a lower gear?
questions.answerA: As you begin to move downward
questions.answerB: As you go downhill and pick up speed
questions.answerC: Before you start going downhill
questions.explanation: You should always slow down and shift into a lower gear before starting down a hill. If you do not begin to drive down a hill at a low enough speed, you risk overusing your brakes, causing them to overheat and fade.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Place as little weight as possible over the axles.
questions.answerB: Place an appropriate amount of weight over the axles.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with how the cargo's weight is distributed.
questions.explanation: When loading cargo, it is important that the weight placed on each axle is neither too little nor too much. Inappropriate loading can interfere with steering, create inadequate wheel traction, or damage the axles.

questions.question: Placards should be used:
questions.answerA: Any time a vehicle is carrying hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: When there is extra space on a truck.
questions.answerC: Only when the amount of hazardous materials on a truck exceeds 200 pounds.
questions.explanation: Warning placards are required to be used any time a vehicle is carrying designated types and amounts of hazardous materials. A placarded vehicle must display placards on all four of its sides.

questions.question: A slack adjuster should move no more than ____ from where it is attached to the push rod.
questions.answerB: Five inches
questions.answerC: One inch
questions.explanation: Before a trip, you should check each slack adjuster after parking, setting wheel chocks, and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure that they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: A truck should be parked:
questions.answerA: So that it must be backed up to leave the space.
questions.answerB: So that it can be pulled forward to leave the space.
questions.answerC: On the grass.
questions.explanation: Because you can't see everything behind you, backing is always dangerous and should be avoided whenever possible. Choose parking spaces from which you can pull forward when you leave.

questions.question: Roads are especially slippery right after it begins to rain because:
questions.answerA: The water mixes with oil and grease on the road.
questions.answerB: Tires are not made to drive in wet weather.
questions.answerC: The water yet hasn't absorbed the dirt and grease.
questions.explanation: Roads are often especially slippery when it first begins to rain. Rainwater forms a slick film when mixed with oil and grease on the road surface that has not yet washed away.

questions.question: To avoid a hazard, you:
questions.answerA: Should always come to a complete stop.
questions.answerB: May need to swerve your vehicle out of the way.
questions.answerC: Should change lanes without looking.
questions.explanation: Stopping is not always the best way to avoid a hazard. If there is not enough space for you to stop to avoid coming into contact with the hazard, swerving out of the way may be your safest option.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerB: Get upset.
questions.answerC: Deal with it and drive at a safe speed.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of developing aggressive driving behavior, you should take measures to manage your stress. One strategy to do this is to simply take a deep breath and accept your circumstances if you realize you will be late to your destination.

questions.question: When coming to a stop, you should apply the brake pedal by:
questions.answerB: Pushing down quickly.
questions.answerC: Pulling up gradually.
questions.explanation: When stopping, you should push the brake pedal down gradually. Braking gradually will help you to maintain proper control of your vehicle.

questions.question: Broken suspension parts:
questions.answerB: Should be repaired, but not immediately.
questions.answerC: Cannot be identified.
questions.explanation: The suspension system performs the vital functions of holding up the vehicle and its load while keeping the axles in place. Defects in the suspension are therefore extremely dangerous.

questions.question: When completing a driver's side parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull forward directly into the parking space.
questions.answerB: Back up past the parking space, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the left of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: When stopping, the brake pedal should be:
questions.answerA: Pressed down quickly with both feet.
questions.answerB: Pressed down gradually.
questions.answerC: Lifted up quickly.
questions.explanation: When braking, push the pedal down gradually to ensure that the vehicle comes to a smooth, safe stop.

questions.question: Which of the following is acceptable if found during a pre-trip inspection?
questions.answerB: Cracks in the tires
questions.answerC: Tires manufactured by different makers
questions.explanation: Be sure to thoroughly inspect your tires before a trip. Tire sizes should not be mismatched, and tires should not be cut, cracked, or otherwise damaged in any way.

questions.question: Hanging meat as cargo is:
questions.answerA: Illegal to transport in most states.
questions.answerB: Always easy to transport.
questions.answerC: Usually unstable.
questions.explanation: An operator should drive with care when transporting a cargo of hanging meat. Such a load is unstable, both because it has a high center of gravity and because the swinging of the meat can affect the driver's handling of the vehicle.

questions.question: The tire load for a tire is stated:
questions.answerA: On the side of the tire.
questions.answerB: On the inside of the tire.
questions.answerC: On the inside of the driver’s door.
questions.explanation: The tire load, or the maximum safe weight that a tire can carry at a given pressure, is stated on the side of each tire.

questions.question: Heights posted at bridges:
questions.answerB: Are legally binding.
questions.answerC: Can be incorrect.
questions.explanation: Never assume that the posted height on a bridge or other overhead object is correct. Even if it was accurate when posted, things may have changed that affect clearance, either permanently (such as a repaving of the road) or temporarily (such as packed snow on the road).

questions.question: What should you do if the braking system cannot build up hydraulic pressure?
questions.answerB: Downshift.
questions.answerC: Hold the brake pedal down as far as it will go.
questions.explanation: If your hydraulic braking system will not build up the pressure needed to slow or stop your vehicle, there are a few possible solutions. Try shifting into a lower gear, pumping the brakes, and/or using the emergency brake.

questions.question: Having weight loaded in a way that creates a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Increases the likelihood of a rollover.
questions.answerB: Increases the likelihood that items will fall down.
questions.answerC: Increases the difficulty of unloading the cargo.
questions.explanation: Transporting cargo that is loaded with a high center of gravity increases the risk that the transporting vehicle will tip over. Cargo should be loaded with a safe weight distribution.

questions.question: To ensure that you do not slow down traffic when driving a large truck, you should:
questions.answerB: Try to pass another vehicle while driving uphill.
questions.answerC: Stay in the right lane whenever possible.
questions.explanation: If a heavy load prevents your vehicle from keeping up with the speed of other traffic, you should stay in the right lane.

questions.question: You may be an aggressive driver if you:
questions.answerB: Slow down and maintain a reasonable following distance.
questions.answerC: Make hand gestures that could anger other drivers.
questions.explanation: Avoid being an aggressive driver by being realistic about your travel time, making allowance for delays, maintaining reasonable following distances, and not making hand gestures that could anger another driver.

questions.question: Regrooved tires:
questions.answerA: Should not be used on any vehicle.
questions.answerB: Should not be used on the front of a bus.
questions.answerC: Should not be used on trucks hauling gravel.
questions.explanation: Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are prohibited on the front wheels of a bus.

questions.question: Always perform the steps of a pre-trip inspection in the same order each time because:
questions.answerA: You will be less likely to forget something.
questions.answerB: You will have more time to complete the inspection.
questions.answerC: It is required by law.
questions.explanation: Completing the steps of a vehicle inspection in the same order before every trip aids in learning what the proper steps are. Additionally, you be less likely to forget a step when going through the checklist in a prescribed order.

questions.question: A lane change:
questions.answerB: Should be done slowly.
questions.answerC: Should be done with a jerking motion.
questions.explanation: Lane changes should be made slowly and smoothly.

questions.question: As the driver of a truck carrying a load, you are responsible for all of the following, except:
questions.answerB: Recognizing poorly balanced weight.
questions.answerC: Knowing the phone numbers of all fire departments along your intended route of travel.
questions.explanation: It is the driver's responsibility to inspect their cargo; recognize overloading or poorly balanced weight; know that the cargo is properly secured and does not obscure the driver's view; and know that the cargo does not restrict access to emergency equipment. The driver is responsible for their cargo even if they were not the one who initially loaded and secured the cargo.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.answerB: The nuts are loose.
questions.answerC: The tires should be replaced.
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts can indicate that the nuts are loose. If you find rust near the wheel nuts, check their tightness before beginning to drive.

questions.question: The effects of alcohol are felt:
questions.answerB: Only after several drinks have been consumed.
questions.answerC: At the legal limit.
questions.explanation: Alcohol impairment can begin with the first drink consumed. It is both illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while impaired by alcohol.

questions.question: Talking on a hands-free phone while driving:
questions.answerB: Only distracts the driver if the driver is speaking.
questions.answerC: Can be distracting to the driver.
questions.explanation: While speaking on a hands-free phone while driving is less dangerous than speaking on a hand-held phone, it is just as likely to mentally distract a driver. Simply engaging in conversation takes their mental focus away from the task of driving.

questions.question: When starting the engine of a truck with a trailer, you can tell that your vehicle's ABS is not working if:
questions.answerA: The yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on.
questions.answerB: The red light on the right side of the trailer flashes three times.
questions.answerC: All the rear lights flash and then turn off.
questions.explanation: When turning on your vehicle's engine, the lights on the dash should come on and then turn off. If the ABS malfunction light stays on, the system is not working properly. In the case of a truck with a trailer, if the yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on once the engine has been started, the system is not working properly.

questions.question: When starting your vehicle, the coolant temperature should:
questions.answerB: Increase gradually.
questions.answerC: Quickly jump from low to high.
questions.explanation: Watch the gauges in your vehicle before starting a trip. After starting your vehicle's engine, the coolant temperature should begin a gradual rise to the normal operating range.

questions.question: When conducting a pre-drive inspection:
questions.answerA: The inspection report is not important.
questions.answerB: The inspection report must only be reviewed if there will be passengers in the vehicle.
questions.answerC: The previous inspection report should be reviewed, if applicable.
questions.explanation: The first step of a vehicle inspection is to review the last vehicle inspection report. Only sign the report if noted defects are certified to have been repaired.

questions.question: When taking a driving test:
questions.answerA: You must supply the same type of vehicle for which you will require a CDL.
questions.answerB: You may supply any type of vehicle, even if it is not the type of vehicle for which you will be using with the CDL.
questions.answerC: The testing station will supply the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Skills tests must be taken in the type of vehicle the applicant plans to drive. The applicant is generally responsible to supply the testing vehicle.

questions.question: If you must leave the roadway and drive on the shoulder in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerB: Get both sets of wheels onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Stay on the shoulder until your vehicle has stopped, if possible.
questions.explanation: If you must drive onto the shoulder to avoid a hazard, stay on it until you come to a stop; then signal, check your mirrors, and merge back into traffic. Avoid braking on the shoulder at speeds higher than about 20 mph. To help maintain control, always keep one set of wheels on the pavement, if possible.

questions.question: When taking the basic vehicle control skills test, failing to exit your vehicle properly during any exercise will result in:
questions.answerB: An extra point against your final score.
questions.answerC: Automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: If your vehicle is hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerB: Not use the brakes.
questions.answerC: Put the vehicle in reverse.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, do not apply the brakes. Instead, slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch. This will help you to regain traction.

questions.question: When loading cargo, weight should be placed:
questions.answerB: As low as possible.
questions.answerC: As far back as possible.
questions.explanation: A vehicle is vulnerable to tipping over if its center of gravity is too high. To prevent this, you should distribute the weight of your cargo evenly and as low as possible.

questions.question: If a vehicle begins to hydroplane, the driver should:
questions.answerB: Release the accelerator and push in the clutch.
questions.answerC: Pull in the clutch and brake.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, you can regain control by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch.

questions.question: When stopping, the brake pedal should be:
questions.answerA: Pressed down quickly with both feet.
questions.answerB: Pressed down gradually.
questions.answerC: Lifted up quickly.
questions.explanation: When braking, push the pedal down gradually to ensure that the vehicle comes to a smooth, safe stop.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections are:
questions.answerB: Needed only for trips longer than 100 miles in length.
questions.answerC: Required by law.
questions.explanation: Federal and state laws require drivers to inspect their vehicles before every trip, regardless of length.

questions.question: Belts in the engine compartment should:
questions.answerB: Not have excessive wear.
questions.answerC: Be greasy.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your vehicle's engine, check the belts for tightness and excessive wear. The amount of "give" that is safe for each belt in a given engine will vary, so learn what is appropriate for your vehicle.

questions.question: If a vehicle has a vehicle inspection report from the previous driver:
questions.answerA: The driver should not conduct a pre-trip inspection and rely on the report.
questions.answerB: The driver should take the vehicle to a mechanic.
questions.answerC: The driver should review the report.
questions.answerD: The driver should speak with the previous driver.
questions.explanation: As the first step of a vehicle inspection, you should review any inspection report left by the previous driver.

questions.question: While driving, you:
questions.answerB: Can make phone calls by pressing more than one button.
questions.answerC: Cannot hold a phone to make a voice call.
questions.explanation: While driving a CMV, reading and sending text messages is prohibited. You may not hold a cell phone to make a voice call or dial a phone by pressing more than one button.

questions.question: What is a retarder?
questions.answerA: A device that prevents a vehicle from going too fast
questions.answerB: A device that prevents a vehicle from being too loud
questions.answerC: A device that improves a vehicle's gas mileage
questions.explanation: Retarders help to slow vehicles, reducing drivers' need to use brakes.

questions.question: Livestock:
questions.answerA: Should never be carried on a trailer.
questions.answerB: Should be placed in the front of a trailer.
questions.answerC: Can create unstable driving conditions.
questions.explanation: Because live animals can lean during curves, and otherwise move in transit, the weight distribution of a cargo of livestock is unstable. Driving with livestock requires special care.

questions.question: If you are convicted of a traffic violation:
questions.answerA: The State will inform your employer.
questions.answerB: You must tell your employer.
questions.answerC: You must tell the shipper.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any kind of traffic violation, in any type of vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days. You must also inform your motor vehicle licensing agency of the violation within 30 days if the conviction happened in another jurisdiction. This rule does not apply to parking infractions.

questions.question: Too much air pressure in a tire:
questions.answerB: Is encouraged on long drives.
questions.answerC: Can be dangerous.
questions.explanation: Tires should never have too much air pressure. Be sure to check your tires' air pressure with a gauge during inspections.

questions.question: Dry bulk tanks:
questions.answerA: Usually have low centers of gravity.
questions.answerB: Usually have high centers of gravity.
questions.answerC: Are usually not allowed to cross railroad tracks.
questions.explanation: Dry bulk tanks require special care to be driven, both because they have high centers of gravity and because the weight of the load can shift in transit.

questions.question: How can you check hydraulic brakes?
questions.answerA: Pump the brake pedal three times then apply firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should not move.
questions.answerB: Pump the brake pedal three times then apply firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should move slowly toward the floor.
questions.answerC: Pump the brake pedal three times then apply firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The brake pedal should slowly rise.
questions.explanation: Check hydraulic brakes by pumping the brake pedal three times before applying firm pressure to the pedal for five seconds. The pedal should not move. If it does, there may be a leak or some other problem in the braking system.

questions.question: Some air brake systems introduce alcohol into the system to:
questions.answerA: Make the brakes work without squeaking.
questions.answerB: Prevent ice from forming in the brake system.
questions.answerC: Prevent people from breathing the air from the system.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems contain an alcohol evaporator. An evaporator introduces alcohol into the system to help inhibit the formation of ice in cold weather.

questions.question: A tread depth of ____ should be in every major groove of a tire that is not in the front of a commercial motor vehicle.
questions.answerB: 2/32 of an inch
questions.answerC: 4/32 of an inch
questions.explanation: For safe operation, a commercial motor vehicle needs a tread depth of 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires, and a tread depth of 2/32 of an inch on other tires.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerB: The truck is properly loaded.
questions.answerC: The cargo is mostly in the front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: It is essential to the safe operation of a CMV that cargo be properly loaded. Improper loading can affect handling and damage the vehicle. Additionally, improperly loaded materials can cause injury or death by falling off of the vehicle.

questions.question: Backing with a trailer is dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is difficult to see behind the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Most trucks do not have the ability to go in reverse.
questions.answerC: Cargo may fall out of the trailer.
questions.explanation: Backing up is always dangerous because it is impossible to see everything that is behind you. Only drive in reverse if it is absolutely necessary.

questions.question: When loading cargo, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Stack items as high as possible.
questions.answerB: Know the weight capacity rating of the suspension system.
questions.answerC: Place light items underneath heavier items.
questions.explanation: It is a driver's responsibility to make sure their vehicle is not overloaded. They must be aware of legal weight limits and the maximum weight that their vehicle is rated to carry, including the weight capacity rating of the suspension system.

questions.question: In icy conditions, a retarder should be:
questions.answerB: Turned off.
questions.answerC: Only used on the rear wheels.
questions.explanation: A retarder may cause a skid when traction is poor, such as when a road is icy, and should therefore be turned off in such conditions.

questions.question: Which gas would cause concern due to a faulty exhaust system?
questions.answerB: Carbon monoxide
questions.answerC: Nitrogen
questions.explanation: A leaking exhaust system can introduce carbon monoxide, which is poisonous, into the cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: An after-trip inspection should be done:
questions.answerB: Once a month.
questions.answerC: After every trip.
questions.explanation: You should always complete an after-trip inspection of your vehicle at the end of a trip, day, or tour of duty. Complete a vehicle inspection report, if required.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the other driver.
questions.answerB: Assume the other driver doesn't see you.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: Whenever you pass another driver, bicyclist, or pedestrian, you should assume as a precaution that they do not see you.

questions.question: During the basic control skills test, you will receive points if you:
questions.answerB: Check your positioning.
questions.answerC: Cross over exercise boundaries.
questions.explanation: The examiner will score the number of times your vehicle touches or crosses an exercise boundary line. Each encroachment will count as an error, resulting in points against your skills test score.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, air pressure should build from 85 to 100 psi within ____ seconds.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for air pressure to build from 85 to 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems. This should take about 45 seconds.

questions.question: Hanging meat:
questions.answerA: Should never be transported by trailer.
questions.answerB: Can be an unstable load.
questions.answerC: Must be approved by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).
questions.explanation: An operator should drive with care when transporting a cargo of hanging meat. Such a load is unstable, both because it has a high center of gravity and because the swinging of the meat can affect the driver's handling of the vehicle.

questions.question: How can a driver maintain alertness while driving?
questions.answerB: Keep the cab warm
questions.answerC: Eat heavy foods
questions.explanation: Eating heavy foods before driving or keeping the temperature in a cab too high can cause a driver to become drowsy while behind the wheel. Exercising and maintaining a healthy diet will help a driver to stay alert while driving.

questions.question: How long should it take for oil pressure to reach a normal level when starting a vehicle?
questions.answerB: About a minute
questions.answerC: About four minutes
questions.explanation: After starting a vehicle's engine, the oil pressure should come up to a normal level within seconds. Do not operate a vehicle if it has oil pressure that is low, dropping, or fluctuating.

questions.question: When passing a row of parked vehicles, a driver should:
questions.answerB: Watch for signs of a person exiting a vehicle.
questions.answerC: Flash their headlights.
questions.explanation: You should be cautious when passing parked vehicles. A person may step out of a parked vehicle or out from between parked vehicles without looking for oncoming traffic. A driver may begin moving their vehicle before realizing you are there.

questions.question: If your license to operate a personal vehicle is revoked or suspended:
questions.answerA: You can get a hardship license to operate a CMV.
questions.answerB: You cannot get a hardship license to operate a CMV.
questions.answerC: Your CDL will not be affected.
questions.explanation: If your license to operate your personal vehicle is revoked, canceled, or suspended, you may not obtain a hardship license to operate a CMV.

questions.question: If the spring brakes are on, you should:
questions.answerB: Press the accelerator.
questions.answerC: Move the steering wheel.
questions.explanation: Do not use the brake pedal when the spring brakes are on. This could damage the brakes by subjecting them to the combined forces of springs and air pressure.

questions.question: You should test the low pressure warning signal by:
questions.answerA: Turning on the engine and applying the trailer hand brake.
questions.answerB: Rapidly pressing and releasing the brake pedal.
questions.answerC: Removing wheel chocks and disengaging the parking brake.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your low pressure warning light functions properly. After allowing the system to charge, you can test the warning signal by rapidly applying and releasing the brake pedal. This will release air from the braking system and the warning signal should come on when pressure drops to a dangerous level.

questions.question: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop after a short distance to:
questions.answerA: Check the tightness of the lug nuts.
questions.answerB: Lower the tire's air pressure.
questions.answerC: See if rocks have gotten into the tread.
questions.explanation: After a tire has been changed, the driver should stop a short distance later to recheck the tightness of the tire's lug nuts.

questions.question: The radiator cap:
questions.answerA: Should not be removed when the coolant is hot.
questions.answerB: Can be removed when the coolant is hot.
questions.answerC: Should be cool to the touch under normal driving conditions.
questions.explanation: Never remove the radiator cap or any part of the pressurized cooling system until it has cooled. Opening the cap while the system is too hot could release steam and boiling water that could severely burn you. If the radiator cap is cool to the touch, the system is likely cool enough for you to open the cap.

questions.question: What is the number one cause of death and injury in a work zone?
questions.answerB: Slow drivers
questions.answerC: Animals crossing the road
questions.explanation: Speeding is the leading cause of death and injury in work zones. Use extra caution when driving near workers in a work zone.

questions.question: What does a vehicle inspection report do?
questions.answerA: Tells the motor carrier about problems that may need fixing
questions.answerB: Ensures that the vehicle is inspected regularly
questions.answerC: Holds drivers accountable for inspecting the vehicle
questions.explanation: Drivers may be required to submit a written vehicle inspection report at the end of each day of driving. The motor carrier must repair any items in the report that affect safety and certify on the report that repairs were either made or unnecessary.

questions.question: Distracted driving can be avoided by:
questions.answerB: Smoking while driving.
questions.answerC: Eating while driving.
questions.explanation: Distractions while driving can be physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as making conversation with a passenger), or both (such as holding a phone to send texts). Strategies to help you avoid distracted driving include pre-programming radio stations; planning out your route in advance; avoiding complex or emotionally taxing conversation while driving; adjusting your mirrors before setting out; and not eating, drinking, or smoking while behind the wheel.

questions.question: When pulled over to the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Rely on your taillights to alert other motorists to your presence.
questions.answerB: Not worry about other motorists.
questions.answerC: Use your four-way emergency flashers to alert other motorists to your presence.
questions.explanation: When stopped on the side of the road, be sure to turn on your vehicle's four-way emergency flashers, especially during times of lowered visibility. Place warning devices within 10 minutes of being stopped.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an indicator of when to upshift?
questions.answerB: RPMs
questions.answerC: Time
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: Of the following, which is the most slippery surface?
questions.answerB: Ice that is wet
questions.answerC: Wet pavement
questions.explanation: Ice becomes wet when the weather is just warm enough to melt the ice slightly. Wet ice is much more slippery than ice that is not wet.

questions.question: ____ make up the emergency brake system.
questions.answerA: Only parts of the parking brake system
questions.answerB: Only parts of the service brake system
questions.answerC: Parts of the parking and service brake systems
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, there are three different braking systems: a service brake system, a parking brake system, and an emergency brake system. The emergency brake system uses parts of both the parking and service brake systems.

questions.question: A thin layer of ice that forms on road surfaces is called:
questions.answerB: Black ice.
questions.answerC: Blue ice.
questions.explanation: Black ice is a thin layer of ice that is clear enough for the road surface to be seen through it. A road covered in black ice may look like it is merely wet. You should be very careful when temperatures are below freezing and the road looks wet.

questions.question: When experiencing cold weather, be sure to check your vehicle's alcohol evaporator:
questions.answerB: Every day.
questions.answerC: Every other week.
questions.explanation: An alcohol evaporator can help prevent ice from building up in an air brake system. In cold weather, the evaporator should be checked and refilled every day.

questions.question: When operating a vehicle with a dual air brake system, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Let the vehicle warm up before driving to ensure that the fuel reaches the engine.
questions.answerB: Let the air compressor build up a minimum of 100 psi pressure in the primary and secondary systems before driving.
questions.answerC: Begin driving just after the vehicle starts.
questions.explanation: Before driving a vehicle with a dual air brake system, allow time for the air compressor to build up a minimum of 100 psi pressure in both the primary and secondary systems. Watch the air pressure gauges to monitor the pressure levels.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an example of a distracted person who should concern motorists?
questions.answerA: A driver talking to a passenger in their vehicle
questions.answerB: A person sitting on a bench waiting for a bus
questions.answerC: A construction worker on the side of the road
questions.explanation: You should be cautious when you are near people who are not paying attention to the road. Drivers and pedestrians who are talking to someone may be distracted by the conversation and not fully paying attention to the road. Workers on or near the road may not be paying attention to traffic because they are focused on their work, and can themselves also be a distraction to drivers.

questions.question: One way to prevent fatigue on long trips is to:
questions.answerB: Text while driving.
questions.answerC: Drink caffeine.
questions.explanation: To avoid becoming fatigued on a long trip, you should take a break after every 100 miles or two hours of driving. Driving through the night, or during any other time when you would normally be asleep, raises the danger of fatigue.

questions.question: If planning to change lanes, your mirrors should:
questions.answerB: Be checked as usual.
questions.answerC: Be checked more often than usual.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should be part of your normal scanning routine, be especially sure to check your mirrors when changing lanes.

questions.question: When you are about to start down a hill, you should switch into a ____ gear.
questions.answerB: Faster
questions.answerC: Lower
questions.explanation: Before starting down a hill, be sure to switch into a low gear. Gravity will increase your vehicle's speed as you travel downhill.

questions.question: If planning to stop on the road to unload cargo, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop suddenly, since you are already on the road.
questions.answerB: Warn other drivers by tapping your brakes.
questions.answerC: Wave your arm out the window to get the attention of other drivers.
questions.explanation: You should tap your brakes and flash your brake lights to warn other drivers any time you plan to slow or stop where other drivers may not expect you to do so. Use this technique when stopping on the road to unload cargo or passengers.

questions.question: Within 10 minutes of stopping on the side of the road, you must:
questions.answerB: Alert local law enforcement.
questions.answerC: Call a mechanic.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, you must place the appropriate emergency warning devices within 10 minutes of stopping.

questions.question: Alcohol evaporators are:
questions.answerB: Used to introduce alcohol into air brake systems.
questions.answerC: Only allowed in the northern parts of the state.
questions.explanation: Some air brake systems have alcohol evaporators, which introduce alcohol into the braking system to help prevent the formation of ice.

questions.question: Which of the following is acceptable if found during a pre-trip inspection?
questions.answerB: Tread of 3/32 of an inch in the grooves of the front tires
questions.answerC: Tires manufactured by different makers
questions.explanation: When checking the tires as part of a pre-trip inspection, make sure the tires have sufficient tread. There should be at least 4/32 of an inch of tread in every major groove of the front tires, and at least 2/32 of an inch of tread depth on the other tires. Tire sizes should not be mismatched.

questions.question: Drivers talking to passengers in their vehicle should be viewed as:
questions.answerB: Distracted drivers.
questions.answerC: Knowledgeable drivers.
questions.explanation: Drivers who are engaged in conversation with passengers may be distracted from the task of driving. Use extra caution when driving near distracted drivers.

questions.question: If other vehicles are having a difficult time getting around your truck on a road with two or more lanes, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive on the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Use the right lane.
questions.explanation: You should stay in the right lane of a multilane road if your vehicle is being slowed down by a heavy load. Allow other vehicles to pass your truck using the left lane.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a warning sign of fatigue?
questions.answerB: Staying within your lane
questions.answerC: Rubbing your eyes
questions.explanation: Potential warning signs of fatigue include difficulty focusing, frequent blinking, or heavy eyelids; yawning repeatedly or rubbing your eyes; daydreaming; wandering or disconnected thoughts; trouble remembering the last few miles you've driven; missing exits or traffic signs; having trouble keeping your head up; drifting from your lane; following too closely; hitting a shoulder rumble strip; or feeling restless and irritable.

questions.question: If a vehicle is power steering-equipped, the hoses should be:
questions.answerB: Securely connected to the battery.
questions.answerC: Carrying fuel.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle equipped with power steering, you should inspect the hoses, pumps, and fluid levels. Specifically check the hoses for leaks.

questions.question: During a static leakage test, what is the maximum leakage rate that is safe for a double combination vehicle?
questions.answerB: 6 psi in one minute.
questions.answerC: 8 psi in one minute.
questions.explanation: When performing a static leakage test on a double combination vehicle with air brakes, the leakage rate should be no more than 3 psi in one minute. If the air leaks from the air brake system at a quicker rate, the vehicle should not be driven because something likely needs to be repaired.

questions.question: Air tank drains should:
questions.answerB: Only be used when it is wet outside.
questions.answerC: Be used to drain the tanks completely.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, air tank drains are used to remove water and compressor oil from the air tanks. When operating a drain, be sure to drain the tank completely.

questions.question: If you are taking the driving test and the route does not include a railroad crossing, you:
questions.answerA: Will not have to do anything related to a crossing.
questions.answerB: May have to explain how you would cross railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Will have to take a different route.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, if your route does not include a railroad crossing, the examiner may ask you to explain and demonstrate the necessary procedures at a simulated location.

questions.question: What is the minimum number of tie-downs required to secure a 10-foot piece of cargo?
questions.answerB: Two
questions.answerC: Three
questions.explanation: On flatbed trailers and trailers without sides, cargo must be tied down. There should be at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. Regardless of the size of the cargo, at least two tie-downs must be used.

questions.question: If air pressure drops to a level between ____, a visual low pressure warning signal should have already activated.
questions.answerB: 80 and 95 psi.
questions.answerC: 65 and 100 psi.
questions.explanation: A visual low pressure warning signal should activate before air pressure drops to a level between 55 and 75 psi. This signal could be a light, a buzzer, or a wig wag.

questions.question: ABS brakes:
questions.answerB: Lock up your vehicle's wheels.
questions.answerC: Prevent your vehicle from accelerating when going uphill.
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up when the driver brakes hard on a slippery surface.

questions.question: If a tire fails, you should:
questions.answerB: Stay off the brakes.
questions.answerC: Swerve.
questions.explanation: Braking after a tire fails can result in a loss of control. Stay off your brakes, if possible, until your vehicle has slowed considerably.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of bad brakes?
questions.answerB: Very thin pads
questions.answerC: Pads free of oil or grease
questions.explanation: When inspecting your brakes, you should check for cracked drums; shoes or pads covered in oil, grease, or brake fluid; and shoes that are missing, broken, or worn dangerously thin.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerB: Can cause mechanical damage.
questions.answerC: Is required on slippery surfaces.
questions.explanation: Always speed up smoothly and gradually so that your vehicle does not jerk. Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage.

questions.question: If you plan to transport hazardous materials, you must pass which endorsement test?
questions.answerB: Hazardous materials
questions.answerC: Passengers
questions.explanation: You must have a hazardous materials endorsement to drive a vehicle of any size that is used to transport defined classes of hazardous materials.

questions.question: If you are being tailgated, you should:
questions.answerB: Allow the vehicle to pass.
questions.answerC: Drive faster.
questions.explanation: If someone is following you too closely, you should open up the space in front of your vehicle to make it easier for the tailgater to pass. Speeding up is counterproductive because the other driver may just continue tailgating you at the higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: A dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Consists of two separate air brake systems that share a single set of controls.
questions.answerB: Is a single air brake system with two different sets of controls.
questions.answerC: Consists of one air brake system for the left side of the truck and one system for the right side of the truck, each with its own set of controls.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. The systems share a single set of brake controls, but each has its own air tanks, hoses, and lines. One system typically operates the regular brakes on the rear axle or axles while the other system operates the regular brakes on the front axle.

questions.question: Backing with a trailer is dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is difficult to see behind the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Most trucks do not have the ability to move in reverse.
questions.answerC: Cargo may fall out of the trailer.
questions.explanation: Backing a truck is always dangerous because the driver may not be able to see everything behind them. CMV operators should avoid backing whenever possible.

questions.question: Hanging meat in a refrigerated truck:
questions.answerA: Is a good way for inexperienced drivers to gain experience.
questions.answerB: Requires a skilled driver.
questions.answerC: Is illegal in most states.
questions.explanation: An operator should drive with care when transporting a cargo of hanging meat. Such a load is unstable, both because it has a high center of gravity and because the swinging of the meat can affect the driver's handling of the vehicle.

questions.question: To determine if a vehicle can handle a load, you must know:
questions.answerB: The tire rating for the front tires only.
questions.answerC: The tire rating for the rear tires only.
questions.explanation: It is a driver's responsibility to make sure their vehicle is not overloaded. They must be aware of legal weight limits and the maximum weight that their vehicle is rated to carry, including the weight capacity rating of the suspension system.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle controls skills test exercise, your vehicle's final position should be:
questions.answerA: In the general area that was described by the examiner.
questions.answerB: In the exact final position described by the examiner.
questions.answerC: Within three feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.explanation: You should finish each exercise with your vehicle in the exact position described by the examiner. You can be penalized for failing to complete an exercise exactly in the manner described by the examiner, potentially resulting in failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: Which of the following is not part of a vehicle’s air brake system?
questions.answerB: Low pressure warning device
questions.answerC: Air filter
questions.explanation: Components of an air brake system include an air compressor, an air compressor governor, air storage tanks, air tank drains, an alcohol evaporator, a safety valve, a brake pedal, foundation brakes, supply pressure gauges, an application pressure gauge, a low air pressure warning signal, a stop light switch, a front brake limiting valve (on some older vehicles), spring brakes, and parking brake controls.

questions.question: You should always be able to stop within:
questions.answerB: 100 feet of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Your view of the road ahead.
questions.explanation: It is essential that your vehicle will be able to stop within the area of the road that you are able to see. This means that you must slow down whenever conditions reduce visibility.

questions.question: What should you do if your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks?
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle and call for assistance.
questions.answerC: Continue trying to get your vehicle off the tracks until you are successful.
questions.explanation: If your CMV gets stuck on railroad tracks, you should immediately leave the vehicle and get away from the tracks. Check the signposts or signal housing at the crossing for emergency contact information and call 911, or another appropriate emergency number.

questions.question: You should maintain at least ____ of following distance per every 10 feet of your vehicle when you are traveling more slowly than 40 mph.
questions.answerB: Two seconds
questions.answerC: Three seconds
questions.explanation: At speeds below 40 mph, you should allow at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle. Follow the same formula when traveling at faster speeds, then add one additional second to your following distance. Remember that larger vehicles require more space to stop than smaller vehicles.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep grade, you switch into a lower gear:
questions.answerB: When you have already started the grade.
questions.answerC: As far down the grade as possible.
questions.explanation: You should shift your vehicle's transmission into a low gear before staring a downhill grade. Be prepared for gravity to increase your vehicle's speed when traveling downhill.

questions.question: Interstate carriers must have what information affixed to both sides of a CMV?
questions.answerB: Model number of the truck
questions.answerC: Destination
questions.explanation: Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations (FMCSR) require carriers to affix the USDOT number to both sides of each CMV in their fleet.

questions.question: When doing a pre-trip inspection, you should:
questions.answerA: Always go through the steps in the same order.
questions.answerB: Be as quick as possible.
questions.answerC: Not worry about small mechanical issues.
questions.explanation: Pre-trip inspections should be conducted in the same way every time. This will reinforce the steps, making it less likely that you will forget to inspect something important.

questions.question: To avoid a collision with a hazard on the roadway:
questions.answerA: You should always try to stop.
questions.answerB: Swerving may be a safer option than stopping.
questions.answerC: You should never swerve.
questions.explanation: Swerving out of the way of a hazard is sometimes safer than trying to stop before reaching the hazard. You can usually turn away from something more quickly than you can come to a complete stop.

questions.question: Wheel rims that have been welded should:
questions.answerB: Be placed on tires in the rear of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Not be used.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe to be used.

questions.question: Who is responsible for the safe operation of a vehicle?
questions.answerB: The mechanic
questions.answerC: The owner
questions.explanation: The person driving a vehicle is responsible for its safe operation. Be sure to perform routine vehicle inspections before operating a commercial motor vehicle.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerB: The truck is properly loaded.
questions.answerC: The cargo is mostly in the front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: It is essential to the safe operation of a CMV that cargo be properly loaded. Improper loading can affect handling and damage the vehicle. Additionally, improperly loaded materials can cause injury or death by falling off of the vehicle.

questions.question: Hanging meat as cargo is usually:
questions.answerB: Dangerous, due to the possible scent.
questions.answerC: Unstable.
questions.explanation: An operator should drive with care when transporting a cargo of hanging meat. Such a load is unstable, both because it has a high center of gravity and because the swinging of the meat can affect the driver's handling of the vehicle.

questions.question: Friction in an S-cam brake is caused when the brake shoes and linings:
questions.answerA: Press against the outside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Press against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.answerC: Push against each other.
questions.explanation: Friction inside a brake drum is caused when the brake shoes and linings push against the inside of the drum. The friction in the drums will slow and stop the vehicle.

questions.question: A Class 1 hazardous material is:
questions.answerB: Radioactive.
questions.answerC: Corrosive.
questions.explanation: The first hazardous materials class includes explosives such as ammunition, dynamite, and fireworks.

questions.question: If you plan to transport hazardous materials, you will:
questions.answerA: Need to obtain a hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerB: Need to drive while using flashing lights.
questions.answerC: Need to wear a gas mask.
questions.explanation: You must have a hazardous materials endorsement to transport any hazardous materials that require the vehicle to be placarded.

questions.question: To stay alert while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Eat a heavy meal before beginning your trip.
questions.answerB: Keep the cab warm.
questions.answerC: Ride with a second person who can share driving responsibilities.
questions.explanation: Splitting driving responsibilities with a second driver lowers the chance that either of you will drive while fatigued. You can also reduce the risk of fatigue by avoiding heavy foods and keeping the interior of the cab cool.

questions.question: Shortly after a tire has been changed, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop to make sure the lug nuts are still tight.
questions.answerB: Repair the brakes.
questions.answerC: Deflate the tire to 10 psi.
questions.explanation: After a tire has been changed, you should stop a short while later to recheck the tightness of the lug nuts.

questions.question: Mirror adjustment can only be checked properly if:
questions.answerB: There is no trailer.
questions.answerC: The vehicle is on a slight incline.
questions.explanation: On a vehicle with one or more trailers, mirror adjustment can only be checked accurately if the trailers are straight. Mirror adjustment should be checked before the start of every trip.

questions.question: When a vehicle is started, the coolant temperature should:
questions.answerB: Rise slowly.
questions.answerC: Jump quickly.
questions.explanation: After an engine is started, the coolant temperature should rise gradually to a normal operating range.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle unattended:
questions.answerA: The parking brake must be always be used.
questions.answerB: The parking brake should never be used.
questions.answerC: Windows in the cab should be lowered.
questions.explanation: Always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle unattended.

questions.question: While driving a CMV:
questions.answerA: You may hold a cell phone to receive a call.
questions.answerB: You may send text messages.
questions.answerC: You may not hold a cell phone to make a call.
questions.explanation: While driving a CMV, you may not make voice calls if you need to hold your phone or press more than one button to do so. Additionally, you may not send or read text messages while driving.

questions.question: When carrying a sealed load, a driver:
questions.answerA: Should unseal the load to ensure safety.
questions.answerB: Should ensure the weight does not exceed weight limits.
questions.answerC: Must go through the container before driving.
questions.explanation: Though a driver cannot inspect a sealed load, they should still ensure that the load does not exceed applicable weight limits.

questions.question: When starting from a stop:
questions.answerA: A vehicle should shift to the right.
questions.answerB: A vehicle should be put into third gear.
questions.answerC: A vehicle should not roll back.
questions.explanation: To avoid hitting anything behind you, make sure that your vehicle does not roll back when you start from a complete stop.

questions.question: When making a tight maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use your mirrors, as they can be distracting.
questions.answerB: Use your mirrors, but not too frequently.
questions.answerC: Use your mirrors frequently.
questions.explanation: It is important for you to be aware of your surroundings at all times. To do this, regularly check your mirrors. You should make a particular point of checking your mirrors when merging, changing lanes, turning, and performing tight maneuvers.

questions.question: When asked to make a lane change during the driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Make the change as soon as the examiner asks, without looking.
questions.answerB: Use your turn signal and change lanes when safe.
questions.answerC: Make the lane change as quickly as possible, even if that means cutting off another driver.
questions.explanation: You will be asked to change lanes during the on-road driving test. When the examiner asks you to do this, you should make the necessary traffic checks and use the proper signals before changing lanes.

questions.question: When driving on a long downhill slope, you should brake by:
questions.answerB: Mostly using the brakes and occasionally downshifting.
questions.answerC: Downshifting and then using the brakes.
questions.explanation: When approaching a long downgrade, you should shift into a lower gear then use proper braking techniques. Using the brakes alone could cause them to overheat and fail. The braking power of the engine, which is maximized by being in a lower gear, will be the principal way of controlling your speed on a downgrade.

questions.question: A person driving with an open window in cold weather may be:
questions.answerB: A person who is dressed inappropriately.
questions.answerC: A person who likes fresh air.
questions.explanation: It is important to observe other drivers' actions and identify clues that a person could be driving impaired. Drivers who have had too much to drink, are sleepy, are on drugs, or are ill can present hazards to other drivers. One sign that a driver may be impaired is that they have their windows rolled down in cold weather.

questions.question: When applying for a hazardous materials endorsement, being found guilty of which of the following is a disqualifying offense?
questions.answerB: Speeding
questions.answerC: Littering
questions.explanation: Amongst other crimes, a felony conviction for arson will disqualify a person from obtaining, renewing, or transferring a hazardous materials endorsement.

questions.question: When braking with ABS, you should:
questions.answerB: Brake normally.
questions.answerC: Brake harder than you would with a different braking system.
questions.explanation: When braking a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should not brake any differently than you would if driving a vehicle with a different braking system.

questions.question: A driver may have:
questions.answerA: An automobile license from one state and a CDL from another.
questions.answerB: Only one license.
questions.answerC: Two licenses: one for automobiles and one for trucks.
questions.explanation: A person may not have more than one license. Violation of this law may be punishable by jail time and/or a fine of up to $5,000.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact with the other driver.
questions.answerB: Assume the other driver doesn't see you.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: Whenever you pass another driver, bicyclist, or pedestrian, you should assume as a precaution that they do not see you.

questions.question: When driving, being aware of what is happening behind you is:
questions.answerB: Important.
questions.answerC: Distracting.
questions.explanation: When driving, it is important to be aware of what is happening behind and to the sides of your vehicle. Mirror checks and head checks should be a normal part of your scanning routine.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerB: Only occurs as a result of people who are physically doing something while driving.
questions.answerC: Can occur as a result of mental activities, such as daydreaming.
questions.explanation: Distractions while driving can be physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as making conversation with a passenger), or both (such as holding a phone to send texts). Strategies to help you avoid distracted driving include pre-programming radio stations; planning out your route in advance; avoiding complex or emotionally taxing conversation while driving; adjusting your mirrors before setting out; and not eating, drinking, or smoking while behind the wheel.

questions.question: What do the two systems of a dual air brake system share?
questions.answerB: An air compressor
questions.answerC: Air tanks
questions.explanation: Both systems in a dual air brake systems share a single air compressor. If the air compressor is damaged, neither system will be able to operate properly.

questions.question: If making a tight turn, the operator of a CMV should:
questions.answerA: Be able to drive as fast as the driver of a car.
questions.answerB: Not be concerned about speed, but focus on the road.
questions.answerC: Warn drivers behind by braking early and slowing gradually.
questions.explanation: Drivers behind you may not anticipate how slowly your CMV must travel to safely make a right turn. You can help warn them in advance by braking early and slowing gradually.

questions.question: If your vehicle is hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn the steering wheel as hard as possible.
questions.answerB: Not use the brakes.
questions.answerC: Put the vehicle in reverse.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to hydroplane, do not apply the brakes. Instead, slow down by releasing the accelerator and pushing in the clutch. This will help you to regain traction.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, it is important to:
questions.answerA: Place as little weight as possible over the axles.
questions.answerB: Place a well-balanced amount of weight over the axles.
questions.answerC: Place weight over only the axles.
questions.explanation: A load of cargo must be properly balanced. Placing too much weight over an axle can damage the axle and make it more difficult for you to steer. Placing too little weight over an axle can cause poor traction, also leading to difficult handling.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason to cover cargo?
questions.answerA: To protect people from spilled cargo
questions.answerB: To protect the cargo from weather
questions.answerC: To protect the cargo from animals
questions.explanation: You should cover your cargo to protect people from the cargo if it spills, as well as to protect the cargo from the weather.

questions.question: When trying to put out an electrical fire, you should:
questions.answerB: Use a B:C extinguisher.
questions.answerC: Use an X extinguisher.
questions.explanation: B:C fire extinguishers are designed to work on electrical fires and burning liquids. Don't pour water on an electrical fire.

questions.question: Distracted driving:
questions.answerA: Is caused only by physical distractions.
questions.answerB: Will be increased by pre-programming radio stations.
questions.answerC: Can be prevented by avoiding conversation with others.
questions.explanation: Distractions while driving can be physical (such as reaching for an object), mental (such as making conversation with a passenger), or both (such as holding a phone to send texts). Strategies to help you avoid distracted driving include pre-programming radio stations; planning out your route in advance; avoiding complex or emotionally taxing conversation while driving; adjusting your mirrors before setting out; and not eating, drinking, or smoking while behind the wheel.

questions.question: What happens when a vehicle hydroplanes?
questions.answerA: The tires lose contact with the road.
questions.answerB: The trailer disengages from the tractor.
questions.answerC: The vehicle becomes easier to control.
questions.explanation: On a wet road, it is possible for a vehicle's tires to lose traction with the road surface and begin to glide along on the layer of water. This is referred to as hydroplaning. Hydroplaning can occur at speeds as low as 30 mph.

questions.question: During the driving test, when asked to make a lane change:
questions.answerA: You should not be concerned with other motorists.
questions.answerB: You should use your turn signal and change lanes when safe.
questions.answerC: You should make the lane change as quickly as possible, even if that means cutting off another driver.
questions.explanation: When asked to make a lane change during the on-road driving test, you should make the proper traffic checks, use your turn signal, and smoothly change lanes when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: The two indicators that determine when you should upshift are:
questions.answerB: Other trucks and driving conditions.
questions.answerC: Timing and road position.
questions.explanation: There are two indicators that determine when you need to shift into a higher gear. One indicator is the engine speed (rpm). You should read your vehicle's manual to learn its rpm range and shift up when you reach the top of that range. The other indicator is road speed (mph). You should learn which speeds each gear can accommodate, then keep an eye on the speedometer and shift up as needed.

questions.question: When doing a pre-trip inspection, you should:
